name: Contains Duplicate II
title: Contains Duplicate II
content:
Given an integer array nums and an integer k, return true if there are two distinct indices i and j in the array such that nums[i] == nums[j] and abs(i - j) <= k.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [1,2,3,1], k = 3
Output: true

Example 2:

Input: nums = [1,0,1,1], k = 1
Output: true

Example 3:

Input: nums = [1,2,3,1,2,3], k = 2
Output: false

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= nums.length <= 105
  • -109 <= nums[i] <= 109
  • 0 <= k <= 105

discussion_posts.name: x4snowman
discussion_posts.content: I am confused about this description.

discussion_posts.name: DontSuCharlie
discussion_posts.content: Why not just say something along the lines of "Find 2 numbers in the array that are equal and are at most `k` apart from each other."?

discussion_posts.name: ankithoney
discussion_posts.content:
For this problem, the below test case is wrong:
nums = [99,99]
k = 2

The correct testcase should be nums = [99,99], k =1.

Because of it I am not able to submit my code.

discussion_posts.content: Do not spam Answers in the Discussion Chat. Avoid it.

discussion_posts.name: ShuoGuo89
discussion_posts.content:
Could anyone tell me why the test case below is true?

[1,0,1,1]
1

The largest difference should be 2 which is greater than k = 1. Isn't it?
Many thanks!

discussion_posts.name: gelatopro
discussion_posts.content:
The testcases for this problem are too weak.

In my first AC solution, I wrote the code

    if (n < k) return false;

, where n is the length of the array.

Clearly, it is wrong(e.g. `nums = {2,2}, k = 3`).


I think the admin should do more serious test before a new problem coming online.

discussion_posts.content:
Why is this case false? [1,2,3,1,2,3], k = 2
the number 3 is in position 2 and 5, that means Math.abs(2-5) === 3
3 >= this is false, so this does not fit the case and i have to return true

am i confused?
